nodes.text: Hypothetical bias in choice experiments causes deviations between hypothetical survey-derived measures and more realistic benchmarks, affecting external validity in a context- and measurement-dependent way

Systematic literature search (Web of Science + supplementary forward/backward search) produced a core dataset of 57 peer-reviewed empirical CE studies comparing hypothetical and more realistic/incentivised choices
Empirical evidence on hypothetical bias in CEs is mixed: magnitude and direction vary by discipline, choice context, design, and outcome measure
Environmental studies show mixed findings: some report no bias after scale correction, others report overstatement of WTP or opt-in rates; moral/public goods tend to show larger HB

Consumer economics studies often find significant upward hypothetical bias in opt-in rates and total WTP, while marginal WTP is sometimes unaffected; incentive-aligned treatments and ecological realism can reduce bias

Health economics studies mostly find negligible or small HB in within-subject comparisons to real choices, with good sensitivity (opt-in) but lower specificity (opt-out) in some cases; scale differences remain common
Transport studies predominantly report significant HB, often a downward bias in valuation of travel time savings, though some non-monetary choice contexts show little or no bias

Psychology and neuroimaging evidence is mixed but explains mechanisms: real versus hypothetical choices differ in brain activation, decision time, and are influenced by affective states (hot-cold empathy gap), product valence (goods vs bads), and personality

A recurring empirical regularity is scale differences between hypothetical and more realistic datasets; adjusting for scale often reconciles marginal trade-off (MRS) estimates even when total WTP or opt-in rates differ

Multiple sources explain HB: lack of payment consequentiality and policy consequentiality, strategic and social desirability responses, cognitive phenomena (hot-cold empathy gap, cognitive dissonance), information and attribute salience, lack of experience and dynamic learning, and design artefacts

Unified definition proposed: hypothetical bias is the deviation in a predefined aggregate or disaggregate measure due to choice data being collected in a hypothetical setting instead of a more realistic (not necessarily naturalistic) setting
Limitation: benchmarking 'true' preferences is often infeasible because many CEs study novel or non-existing alternatives and naturalistic revealed-preference data are rare or imperfect proxies

Conclusion and recommendation: HB is an undeniable but heterogeneous issue; testing across degrees of realism, accounting for scale, tailoring mitigation to identified sources (incentive alignment, contextual tangibility, cheap talk/certainty calibration, immersive presentations), and using domain-specific benchmarks improve evaluation and external validity
